awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Nuclear Science at Texas A&M University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the renewal of the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site in nuclear physics at Texas A&M University.  The site will support twelve undergraduates per year in ten weeks of research during the summer months.  Involvement in research at the undergraduate level is an important component in increasing the numbers and preparation of students entering graduate programs. This site primarily targets students who lack opportunities to do research in the field of Nuclear Science at their home institutions.  

The student research projects are at the leading edge of Nuclear Science, including sub-fields such as nuclear astrophysics, weak interactions, nuclear dynamics and thermodynamics, nuclear structure, the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC), atomic ionizations, and radiation effects. There are proposed projects both in theoretical and experimental Nuclear Science.  The Cyclotron Institute is a Department of Energy (DOE) Nuclear Physics Center of Excellence. The facilities include a K500 superconducting cyclotron, a K150 cyclotron and associated state-of the art detector systems. The Cyclotron Institute and the department of physics are also home base for involvement in experiments at other facilities, and the faculty are leading scientists in the field and have a history of working with undergraduates in their research programs.

por.por_cntn:
This grant enabled 42 undergraduate students between the summer of 2017 and the summer of 2021 to experience cutting edge research through this REU program. During the summer of 2020, the program was unfortunately not able to safely host any REU students due to the pandemic. Support for each student included travel to and from the university, housing while the students are on-site, a stipend and can also include travel to and from a conference the October following their participation in the program. The intended students for this program are those that lack the opportunity to perform nuclear science research at their home institution and those students that are from underrepresented groups in the scientific community.

Each student spent 10 weeks on-site at the Cyclotron Institute at Texas A&M University participating in a research project in nuclear science. The types of projects included hands-on experimental projects, purely theoretical ones, primarily data analysis projects as well as some that required a combination of methods. All students had a faculty or research scientist mentor and also worked closely with the postdoctoral researchers, graduate students and other undergraduate members that comprise their advisors research group. During their time with us, the students are provided with professional development and outreach activities. They are also given opportunities to meet and talk with people, often alumni, who now find themselves in many walks of life, both in and out of research.

Every summer the students are required to present posters on their work to the A&M campus and 10-minute oral presentations at the Cyclotron Institute. Thirty-three of the students also presented their work at the Division of Nuclear Physics conference. This conference is the annual, national conference for nuclear science which is perhaps the most well-attended conference in the country for this field of research. The students not only get to present their research at a poster session, but they get the chance to directly interact with potential future advisors as well as learn about the top nuclear science graduate programs in the country at a graduate school fair. During the time frame of this grant, 7 papers were published in peer-reviewed journals with some of these students credited as authors including three papers where the student was the first-author. More papers are also in development with the hope of achieving publication.

While publications, presentations and progression in cutting edge research are laudable outcomes our primary goal is the development of the students.   This is accomplished by providing these students with the opportunity to envision a future STEM career and the tools to pursue that career through a research experience that many of them cannot get at their home institutions. Through this program we aid the students in determining a long-term career paths, whether that be in research or not, nuclear science or some other field. In this regard, we see an overwhelming success. A significant number of our students indicate on an end-of-experience survey that this program has helped them narrow down their desired career paths. It is in this regard that we find our program a success and look forward to continuing this program in the future.
